Title: Multiple wine products scanning at incorrect prices across Scotland, Wales and Ireland stores
Action: Introduce a peer review process for master data changes to ensure their accuracy before being sent to downstream systems, particularly POS.
Action updates:
Once changes are made in SAP master data, a report will be extracted on the same day before the SAP cutoff at 16:30 to validate the modifications. Any anomalies identified will be corrected in collaboration with the SAP team before the cut off.

If discrepancies are detected after the data has been sent to downstream systems, reactive recovery will be initiated through the major incident management process, involving POS, FMD, and other downstream systems to implement manual corrections. POS has an existing capability to adjust prices before stores opens.

Title: Delay in sending order payment messages from POS Beanstore to Sterling and CSSM

To address this, a comprehensive analysis will be conducted to identify the technical challenges or issues faced by the relevant associate. Based on the findings, a plan will be developed to improve the process and ensure timely information is provided, reducing the time required for impact assessment.

Title: Delay in sending order payment messages from POS Beanstore to Sterling and CSSM
Action: Revisit the refund process for customer order cancellations.
Action updates: Currently, the contact center is responsible for reaching out to customers and processing refunds. However, further discussions between the POS and Sterling teams will take place to explore a more system-driven approach to streamline the refund process.

Title: Delay in sending order payment messages from POS Beanstore to Sterling and CSSM
Action: Amend the 3hr time threshold to 6hr within Sterling to reduce the impact on order cancellation count - Agree with Customer POs by assessing any cascading effect before deploying in prod.
Action updates: The current time threshold in Sterling for customer orders, from placement to payment, is set at three hours. The product team will work with the product owner to extend this to six hours, allowing more time for issue investigations and reducing order cancellations. Implementing this change requires a release process, and a detailed assessment will be conducted to identify any potential cascading effects before deployment to production.

Title: Delay in sending order payment messages from POS Beanstore to Sterling and CSSM

Action updates: Currently being explored

Title: Delay in sending order payment messages from POS Beanstore to Sterling and CSSM
Action: Explore options to automate the reset process for POS channels that enter a retry state.
Action updates: During the issue, the impacted POS sender channel required manual intervention for reset, which delayed the recovery process. To mitigate future impact and expedite resolution, we are exploring automation options to reset channels automatically when they enter a retry state.

Title: Delay in sending order payment messages from POS Beanstore to Sterling and CSSM
Action: Configure a queue depth alert within the POS system to effectively monitor message backlogs in the queues. Additionally, update the Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) to include a step for validating external sender channels during incident triage.
Action updates: While there were previous alerts in the POS system, they did not provide sufficient insight for effective issue identification. To address this, a queue depth alert will be configured to detect message backlogs more accurately. The SOP will also be updated to incorporate a step for proactively validating external sender channels, ensuring quicker identification and resolution of potential issues.

Title: Delay in sending order payment messages from POS Beanstore to Sterling and CSSM
Action: Perform a full analysis of the logs within POS and the MQ environment to determine the root cause of the issue.
Action updates: Initial investigations indicate a communication error on one of the POS BeanStore nodes. Additionally, as an MQ upgrade took place in the morning, followed by another deployment within the MQ landscape for a separate issue, further investigation is underway. A follow-up call is scheduled to finalize the root cause statement for this incident.

Title: SAP POSDTA application was inaccessible

Title: SAP POSDTA application was inaccessible

Title: SAP POSDTA application was inaccessible
Action: Implement a locking mechanism within the Azure network layer to prevent inadvertent deletion of active VNet peers or subscriptions.
Action updates: The cloud team is in the process of configuring this mechanism to ensure that active VNets and subscriptions cannot be deleted in error.

Title: SAP POSDTA application was inaccessible
Action: Document all third-party subscriptions where access is unavailable to verify the status of underlying VNet peers, preventing inadvertent deletions within the Azure network layer.
Action updates: The cloud team will identify all third-party SaaS subscriptions and their respective owners to ensure a thorough impact assessment before proceeding with any security cleanup activities.

Title: SAP POSDTA application was inaccessible
Action: Conduct a detailed review of the Azure subscription decommissioning process to prevent ad-hoc deletion of stale VNet peers. Identify owners for all subscriptions, particularly third-party ones, to enable thorough impact assessments before any deletions.
Action updates: As per the existing process, VNet peers should be deleted when a subscription is decommissioned. However, in this case, the Customer Cloud team lacked access to assess the impact due to the SaaS nature of the subscription. Going forward, we will streamline owner consultations during cleanup activities to ensure proper impact assessment and mitigate the risk of inadvertent deletions.

Title: Inflated Allocations for Thatcham (Foods) RDC impacting stock deliveries to stores
Action: Assess the overall observability within GIST to identify significant volumes of stock adjustment messages or inflated allocations at the store level.
Action updates:
15/04 - In this incident, the smoke test performed by GIST was not communicated to Customer which had actually caused the inflated order volume for stores. However, technically there is no scope of configuring an alert within GIST based on the amount of increased volume of stock adjustment messages as these are not supposed to be sent to stores. Going forward, communication for any smoke tests will be provided to Customer and the DWS change will not be attempted in future which eliminates the scope of issue recurrence. In addition, there are predefined threshold configured within GIST to identify a spike in volume of stock adjustment messages. 
We are currently working with GIST to analyze their monitoring mechanisms and identify areas for improvement, aiming to enhance proactive detection of such issues in the future

Title: Delay in processing Relex batch impacting NDC Allocations, Foods Supplier orders
Action: In the PIR Relex advised that they realised the impact of the issue quite late in the day after the issue started, which resulted in a delay of communicating possible impacts to Customer.  Relex are working on playbooks with different scenarios including prioritisation of actions to include communication.
Action updates: 19/03:  The root issue was traced to a network  switch where one port/cable combination experienced a partial failure, leading to increased error rates. While Relex is designed to automatically failover in cases of complete cable failure (an industry-standard practice already in use at RELEX), this partial failure did not meet the criteria to trigger automatic failover. As a result, some network traffic was disrupted. Relex has implemented enhancements to monitoring as recommended by their vendor which ensures quick detection and have quick response to similar issues in future without introducing unnecessary complexity or risk to network.

Title: Delay in processing Relex batch impacting NDC Allocations, Foods Supplier orders
Action: It is essential that when we initiate the batch process again, we commence from the very beginning rather than from any subsequent point. Failing to do so may result in incomplete data being displayed in the user interface, along with calculations that have not been executed. Ensure that the Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) is updated accordingly.
Action updates:
01/04: gagan is saying that it is not possible to restart the batch from the beginning without incurring impact.  Best practice from Relex is to start from point of failure, the SOP has been updated and engineers have recorded the learnings.

Title: Customers were unable to check out on International Sites from 5:29 to 6:24
Action: Follow up RCA and preventative measures with SFCC
Action updates:
RCA:  The Technology team and third-party vendor determined the initial root cause of the incident was a software bug that caused the load balancer to reboot. Typically, the pair of load balancers remain in sync to allow a graceful failover. In this case, there was a subset of VIP pools that were not configured the same way on the passive load balancer. The third-party vendor identified a further bug that was deemed to be the cause of the load balancers not remaining in sync.
The Technology team further addressed this issue by executing a change to sync the passive load balancer after the disruption. The Technology team also implemented alternate telemetry to identify when load balancers are out of sync.

Preventative action:
To maintain the performance level that our customers expect from Salesforce and to prevent this defect from recurring, our focus is on continuous improvement. The Technology team has identified and is implementing the following actions:
Complete:
? Collaborated with the third-party vendor: The Technology team investigated the impacted load balancer to identify the full root cause of this incident with the vendor.
In Progress:
? Adding additional monitoring: The Technology team is implementing a configuration drift monitoring system between active/passive load balancers.
? Creating a remediation plan while the bug still exists: The Technology team is investigating a remediation plan for load balancers containing the identified bug.

04-03-2025 - Follow up email sent to Hisham and Chokkanathan, awaiting feedback on all action items

Title: Customers were unable to check out on International Sites from 5:29 to 6:24
Action: SFCC service disruption alert timing to be reviewed.
Action updates:
20-03-2025 - Tapas Rajan Prusty confirmed that Enhanced Monitoring has been set up, a  configuration drift monitoring system has been implemented to continuously track and maintain synchronization between active and passive load balancers.

Title: Hand Held Terminal connectivity issues
Action: Determination of Final Root Cause
Action updates:
26/03 - Statement from Richard Burrows suggesting closure - Given the business impact to Customer was minimal Id suggest drawing this one to a close.  Id only really want to follow up if this was part of a wider period of ongoing disruption, but if its an isolated incident as it appears to be, then probably not much point.  I suspect the impact to GXO of a central network issue will likely be considerably greater than the impact to Customer outlined below, so Id work on the basis its being followed up by GXO internally

Root cause - no further details will be provided: The issue was triggered by packet loss on the Virgin Media links at our Node4 DC. This issue was resolved with manual intervention due to the connected hardware going into a hung state. No further preventative action is possible in this specific scenario. 
14-03-2025 - Node 4 have confirmed the issue was there end and a restart was required, however the details of the Root cause is unknown at this given point of time.

04-03-2025 - Follow up email sent to Paul looping Vivek, awaiting feedback on all action items
The initial root cause was confirmed to be the network disturbance in the WAN due to which the Firewall blocked traffic. However, we do not have clarity if the issue was with the last mile Provider or the ISP. We also need to know what kind of disturbance created this service disruption.

Title: Central network connectivity issue impacting various services
Action: There was latency at the pack benches in Donington after the internet traffic was switched to Swindon, while cloud connect traffic remained at Stockley Park. This latency occurred because the internet traffic needed to traverse the Swindon and Stockley Park firewall through the intersite link to access the internet, increasing the number of sessions and overall bandwidth utilisation. Title: Digital Receipts sent to customers for historical transactions
Action: Investigate the root cause of the API issue within the Yocuda infrastructure, review the recovery actions performed by Yocuda, and assess the mitigations they have implemented to prevent similar scenarios in the future.
Action updates:
07/01: Please find below the root cause and preventive actions from Yocuda: 
Root cause: 
At 18:50 a node failed within one of the internal databases of the Yocuda platform. 
An automated graceful failover to a replicated node did not occur as the failure was not detected.
Yocuda performed a manual failover and the issue was resolved at 19:59.
Preventive Actions:
The failure detection mechanism has since been enhanced. If this scenario reoccurs then no manual intervention will be required and no outage will occur.
The unusual cause of this issue meant that the Yocuda API responded with "422 Store not found" for all incoming receipts.
If this scenario did reoccur in the future then it (and any other internal errors) will now respond with "500 Internal Server Error"
18/12: A call has been scheduled with Yocuda to discuss on the root cause of the issue.
06/12: The team are collaborating with Yocuda to understand the cause and resolution details. ETA: 19/12

Title: Demand Notifications & Order Fulfilment messages not processing from Castle Donington WMS into OMS
Action: Identify the root cause and a permanent fix for the uninterruptable processes on the virtual machines.
Action Owner: Pappusamy, Sivasubrmani. Selvapillai, Sathish, Rajasekaran Subramaniyum
Action updates: The root cause was attributed to uninterruptable sleep processes within the mule application resulting in no messages processing from mule to WMS. However, the actual reason for the uninterruptable process during the incident is yet to be determined. A high priority case was raised with Redhat for investigations, and they identified that the blocking sessions due to uninterruptable process had resulted with high load to the systems. To determine the reason behind the uninterruptable process Redhat requires additional logs on the VMCore (VM snapshots) to identify the Mutex owner of the blocking sessions. An action has been agreed to capture the VM snapshots before performing the VM (virtual Machine) restart during the issue reoccurrence, to help determine the root cause and a permanent fix

Title: Store tills were offline across the estate
Action: Review and enhance the alerting mechanisms within the network layer to proactively detect memory leaks on the Stockley Park F5 load balancer.
Action updates:
10/12: Complete as alerting is in place and checked.
An existing alert is in place to detect memory leaks on the Stockley Park F5, and this alert was successfully triggered on the day of the incident to identify the issue. It has been noted that the memory utilization of the Stockley Park F5 device is already at 96%.
To address this, there is a plan to decommission the virtual F5 servers, as most of the services load-balanced through them have already been decommissioned. This decommissioning will release 4GB of memory back to the device.
Additionally, as part of future enhancements, the Beanstore application will be migrated to virtual F5s to eliminate dependency on the current F5 and mitigate risks associated with similar scenarios. 
The problematic F5 device will ultimately be decommissioned and replaced with an alternative solution as part of the Stockley Park exit strategy.

Title: Carrier label printing issues at Ollerton DC on 14/11
Action:
To prevent future disruptions to print functionality, we have identified two options for configuring a retry policy on the print queues:

 

Retry Mechanism with Timeout: Configure the print queue to automatically retry failed print jobs for up to 5 minutes. If the job is still not processed successfully within this timeframe, it will be automatically deleted from the queue.
Error Handling Policy: Implement an error policy on the print queue to ensure that a failed print job does not disrupt the queue. This will prevent job pileups and ensure the continuous flow of print tasks.
Action updates:
30/01: Jafar is on annual leave, followed up with Jeeva and awaiting updates. 
As these changes involve modifications to the print queue configurations, it has been agreed to implement them after the golden quarter to avoid impacting peak operations.

Title: WMS application was inaccessible impacting Milton Keynes DC operations
Action: Since this change was implemented a year ago, there is insufficient evidence to determine whether the Oracle Client was installed or if an underlying issue might have caused its uninstallation. Therefore, we have agreed to explore the feasibility of incorporating an appropriate logging mechanism after Oracle Client installations to ensure clear documentation of any actions taken on the Oracle database.
Action updates:
28/11: We could find the installation logs outside the oracle client installation directory and utilized the same for our analysis. The oracle client was initially installed on the primary server on the same directory during the issue time, hence it reflects the logs on 25th Oct
Based on the findings, we could see that Oracle 19c client was not installed in secondary application server - hlxp00dc141. We will append the Oracle client installation document to share this as evidence for any Oracle client installation on application servers. Additionally, validation and sign-off is required from both application and DB teams to ensure there is no gaps in this process.

Possible options:  1. Card
 Visa
 Mastercard
 Amex
2. Apple Pay
3. Google Pay
4. Sparks
Any/all of these on/off in POG so it would work for both old and new world.
The caveat - Gift Card, voucher, ClearPay and IFL would work as normal BUT not for a split payment.
Need to decide whether or not to take any of this work forward

Title: Intermittent label printing issues at Brands Thorncliffe DC
Action: As a proactive measure, we have reached out to RedHat for recommendations on best practices for performing cluster activities. We have also shared our analysis based on previous issues observed with the Linux cluster and are currently awaiting their feedback
Action updates: 28/11: On that day, site was able to print after the services were failovered to passive node. RedHat suggested us to get an outage window and failback the services from passive to active node and execute few commands to trace the issue. However, we didn't execute those commands as the issue didn't appear when failback was completed. We have relevant documents detailing recovery actions from Redhat to restore services in similar instances

Title: Intermittent label printing issues at Brands Thorncliffe DC

Title: Store colleagues experiencing issue authenticating when accessing SSO applications

It would be difficult to provide an accurate analysis without have a complete log for the entire user flow after clicking the SPO link in your app launcher portal, this is mainly because we cannot assume the status of the SPOIDCRL cookie presented to SharePoint without having hard evidence to support our analysis.  The issue hasnt happened again  This action can be closed.

Title: Windows CE (compact edition) HHTs unable to connect to the network across various Foods and C&H DCs
Action: After applying any change to the group policy object, a reboot should be done so that the changes can take effect, we can see that this reboot was done but we need to investigate why the change did not take effect. At this stage the feeling is that the reboot was done too early and the change did not have time to replicate across the servers.  We need to investigate this further - and review the method used - 15 minutes is needed to allow replication.
Action updates:
09/01: Muthu reconfirmed that Microsoft had no answers for the delay in replication of the change after the immediate restart of the server and also this is related to the HHT's being not compatible. Closing the action as the HHT's upgrade is being tracked as part of another action with Arundel and Colin to raise a risk.

Unless they allow from network layer, we cannot disable legacy TLS protocols. Need to get the plan of action with the Network team to allow latest TLS Protocols to sort out this issue."

Title: Carrier label printing impacted across various C&H DC's
Action: Identify the logic behind triggering the issue on 1st Oct, whether there are any jobs which process the changes made overnight:
Action updates:
21/11: The Customer Carrier Management Team is a team of Customer Business Users. It is their accountability to have full administrative rights to the Sorted carrier management system. In fact, one of the main reasons why Customer decided to migrate from the Metapack carrier management system to the Sorted carrier management system in 2020 was that the Sorted Carrier Management System allows business users to have full administrative control over the system which is fundamental to their business operation. It was therefore entirely correct that the Customer Carrier Management Team should be regularly housekeeping unnecessary user accounts. What the Customer Carrier Management Team user was not aware of at the time, was that the user account in the name of Gary Bennett is, in fact, the Sorted Ship API key account. Since the incident on 1st October, the Customer Business Carrier Management Team has now learned the lesson and will leave the user account in the name of Gary Bennett untouched until a more resilient and appropriate system of site-specific Sorted Ship API key accounts will be set up during Q4.
This incident was caused purely by a BAU business user housekeeping adminstrative process and has nothing to do with overnight batch jobs or anything similar.
Awaiting updates from Sorted

Title: Carrier label printing impacted across various C&H DC's
Action: Identify any other user accounts linked to the core authentication API for other DCs
Action updates:
08/10: It has been confirmed that the same User Account  (Gary Bennett) has been used in the configuration of all the Customer Dispatcher warehouse sites integration with Sorted Ship. There are no other User Accounts which are at risk of causing the same issue if housekept.
Bradford C&H warehouse uses a different warehouse management system (not Dispatcher) and, in consequence, the integration architecture with Sorted Ship is designed differently. It is, nevertheless, our intention that the eventual API key model that we adopt in Q4 will follow the same pattern across all shipping locations (warehouses), including the Bradford Clothing & Home warehouse. In fact, the Customer Solution Architect designed a more robust API key structure a couple of years ago as part of a different project, but the design was not progressed (at the time) to implementation.

Since the maintenance of user accounts is BAU functionality and is owned by the Customer Carrier Management Team, there is no option to prevent access to the account by any user with full admin permissions. The Customer Carrier Manageemnt Team has already completed an audit of users who have administrative permissions to Sorted Ship and anyone whose role does not require administrative access has been removed

Title: Message processing issues from WMS to WCS impacting CD operations
Action:
Review the threshold on the volume of failed records in the interface table to identify if they are valid or genuine.
Alerting is in place on WMS interface queue  Understand what actions were performed and make necessarily changes to prevent incident . Revisit the E2E process after an alert gets triggered, expectation is no failed records by EOD in WMS
Action updates:
30/10: Alerts for key table interface failures are monitored through a controlM job that runs every 30 minutes. A threshold has been set to raise an incident if failures in key tables exceed 500 within this 30-minute window. This setup prevents false alerts, as line records often initially fail but are reprocessed successfully once header records are processed.
Additional steps are in progress to automate the clearance of redundant failures, tracked under a jira JDATE10540.
01/10: Alert Threshold is yet to be reveiewed & confirmed.
In progress

Title: Central issue at Blue Yonder impacting ability to access SRD via Open Access and WLM applications
Action: The issue was identified through Customer alerting, however the BY communications were not sent on time to confirm the outage.
Action updates: BY has agreed to improve their Major incident management process to ensure that communications are sent out in a timely manner. Also, BY is working out on a status page, to notify the outage details on their portal - Which will be worked upon by them via backlog- as this is a long term action

Title: Central issue at Blue Yonder impacting ability to access SRD via Open Access and WLM applications
Action: This is the second instance of Blue Yonder central change impacting our services, Blue Yonder has been advised to review their change management process and to ensure the stability of our services during the peak trading period.
Action updates: Blue Yonder has agreed to review their change management process, as part of which the doer/checker process has been rigorously enforced to prevent human errors. Also, they have introduced Arista CloudVision configuration management tool to implement their changes on Arista devices in order to prevent human errors. Furthermore, they have consented to limit the execution of changes during weekdays unless absolutely required.

Title: Central issue at Blue Yonder impacting ability to access SRD via Open Access and WLM applications
Action: It took around five hours on the day of the incident to restore services and assess the viability of resilience in the event of such disruptions
Action updates: Although BY has a disaster recovery setup in place, the root cause of the problem was identified right away at the beginning of the incident and a recovery plan was quickly created. Thus, the BY tech team did not declare the DR initiation.  The recovery plan required testing to be carried out within the BY environment which took time. However, they have been advised to review their DR process to ensure stability.

Title: Digital Cafe kiosks were unavailable on 13th Aug and 15th Aug
Action: There is a load balancing mechanism at Counter Solutions for the API transaction traffic (kiosks), however, during the issue on 13th Aug, we have seen a complete outage across all the Digital Cafes. Evaluate the current load balancing set up to ensure the traffic is evenly distributed across the virtual machines.
Action updates:
27/02: After sending multiple escalations, there had been no further response to this action. Agreed with business to close it off and scrutinise in future scenarios.
06/01: PM has spoken to Paul and have sent another chaser email to DN for an urgent update. ETA: 10/01

21/11: A further escalation to Darren will be done today to get some answers from Counter Solutions
14/11: Inspite of sending multiple emails to DN & CS, there had not been any response, therefore, it has been escalated to Paul Dasan Cutting who is currently following up with Account managers, we are awaiting an update by Monday, 18th Nov

A follow-up email has been sent to DN requesting a response from CounterSolutions. We will continue to work with DN, supported by service leads and the Digital Cafe product team, to expedite a response.
19/09: EVen after multiple follow ups from Service lead and Customer stakeholders, we have not received the PIR document which is supposed to capture the updates on these actions. Therefore, SIAM has now escalated to the product leads to further escalate to DN or Counter Solutions in streamlining this process.
28/08: The way that the load balancing works between the VMs is not cut and dry to 1 VM serving X amount of devices and VM2 the rest. Each request from the kiosk can be sent to either VM1 or VM2. Therefor in a single transaction journey the start basket request could be sent to VM 1 and then add item request could go to VM2 and so on throughout the journey. This would therefore flag the failed requests on the kiosk as an error based on which VM was serving the request at that time.
There are multiple calls throughout a customer journey  if there is an issue with one of the VM, it takes the session back to homepage.
21/08: Within Counter Solutions infrastructure, as one of the VMs had a problem, the load balancer was unable to determine the health of the VM and therefore, by default only traffic going through VM1 should have a problem. Awaiting further update from CS

Title: Foods (Relex and Quantum) ordering and allocations were inflated
Action: Root cause behind the partial data generation in SAND to ASO.

08/10: As stated below we need to stablise the connection and this wil be done by upgrading out Azure SDK - Puvi to provide a backlog ticket - FSCLT1-5836
01/10: Puvi is out of office but Lisy was appraised. ETA amended
17/09: Microsoft replied and advised they that found AMQP link timeouts due to the increased volume of incoming requests this led a rapid expansion in entity size - we have asked Puvi what caused the volume increase. Due to timeouts some message didnt reach the service Bus,  the Microsoft server didn't process the messages and the receiver did not consume. Although later ASO re-established the connection and messages were processed.MS asked us to upgrade our Azure SDK to a newer version - Puvi to talk to various stakeholders.
10/09: Puvi advises that the Microsoft colleague dealing with this has gone on leave.  Puvi will chase again.  
03/09: On the incident day, Microsoft had identified connectivity issues within their infrastructure, all relevant logs have been provided to Microsoft and investigations are in progress. 
Update 27/08: Puvi advised that we are still awaiting Microsoft to come back with updates.  
The root cause is suspected to be due to an issue at the MS end. Relevant logs have been shared with MS and we await further updates on the RCA.

Title: Foods (Relex and Quantum) ordering and allocations were inflated
Action: Do we have the right alerting/recon mechanism within ASO/SAND service?
Action updates:
03/09: Through the weekly catch up with Naveen, it was advised that the ASO team have confirmed that a threshold for the SAND extract in NextGenFOA has been configured, in case of an issue where there is a breach/mismatch/partial data in SAND, a Sev 1 alert will be triggered. Once the alert gets triggered, the Next Gen FOA will engaged ASO team for further triage. 
27/08 - SAND is calculated from ASO.  Alerting is not possible for intermittent connectivity.  If its a full system down we have alerting in place.  The NGFOA and ASO teams are working in the threshold for the SAND extract
20/08 - We have the right alerting within ASO and SAND service. However, during the incident, the SAND service was not fully unavailable rather it was intermittent, thus no alerts were generated.   Also, there is a challenge in alert/recon configuration based on the SAND data volume through comparison because the data varies everyday based on the time/day/business requirements. However, the product team will further analyse for any possible alerting mechanism. Also a threshold will be defined for comparing the data volume with previous weeks data

Title: C&H weekly sales data understated by 3.7 M in MP and SSI reports
Action: As per the root cause as the 2nd iteration of the SAP BW extractor job had a dependency on i60 completion with a tolerance limit of 120 mins of execution, it was suggested to increase the limit to 180 minutes. Review the implications of the increase of tolerance limit in cSAP BW extractor from 120 to 180 mins. Is there a risk to downstream critical flows?
Action updates:
19/09: Increased the tolerance limit of CSAP BW extractor from 120 to 180 mins to ensure the data is sent from ECC during an overrunning scenario
18/08: By increasing the tolerance limit of cSAP BW extractor to run its 2nd iteration until 3am, we need to review the implications to the downstream systems.

It has been confirmed that Business Objects, MP and SSI have their SLOs at 12:00 noon so there should not be any impact.

 

For BEAM reports, GMOR team will enhance their not started alerts to ensure a proactive communication is sent across to BEAM team on the anticipated delay.

Title: C&H weekly sales data understated by 3.7 M in MP and SSI reports
Action: During the MIM bridge, it was advised, that the i60 job in SAP ECC had overrun due to higher volume of idoc failures to be processed. Review the idoc volume for 10th Aug when compared to 3rd Aug to define the reason behind the overrunning job.
Action updates:
27/08: It was confirmed that as the data volume coming from POS is huge, it is not feasible to identify the reaon behind the job failure. 
18/08: The teams have compared the idoc volume between 10th Aug and 3rd Aug. However, it seems like i60 job had to process 40M idoc on 3rd Aug and completed at 01:40. However, on 10th Aug, the i60 job had to process 36M data which completed at 02:30. There is a possibility that i60 had to reprocess high volume of idoc failures which could have resulted in the job to overrun. Whilst comparing the idoc failure stats, the volume looks usual, we do not have the idoc failure stats for 3rd August, as the data is purged as per design. This needs further investigation to ascertain the reason behind the job overrun

05/11: Update from Ian: We have reviewed the major web conferencing platforms, features, pricing and licensing etc. The best fit for the stated requirements appears to be Webex. This platform would provide a completely seperate web conferencing platform from Microsoft Teams with dial-in capability and a dial-out add-on license available, both of which support India numbers and the other countries stated. Webex business £162 per host per year. Meetings up to 200 participants or Webex starter £114 per host per year - 150 participants. Both include local toll dial-in for UK, Ireland & India. Dial-out add-on available for £357 per host license per year (supports UK, Ireland and India). Note: max meeting duration 24 hours, prices quoted here are MRSP for annual billing (monthly pricing available). Zoom and Google Meet both have some limitations around dial-in/dial-out support for India so are not recommended above the Webex solution. Discuss with Sathish/Dinesh

Title: Multiple servers which are running as primary in Swindon moved to Stockley
Action: The failover of the servers from Swindon to Stockley occurred very quickly after the reboot of the Nexus 7k.  There is no time setting on the VSAN or witness server that we can set to allow the system to recover from any disconnect prior to failing over.  We have raised this with Broadcom (previously known as VMware).  Do we want the failover to be automated, semi-automated or manual to give us more control?  consult with Broadcom.
Action updates: 26/7: Broadcom confirmed that there is no delay timer on the vSAN or the Witness to delay the DR in case of a failure scenario as it polls for heartbeat every second. This DR situation is always automated by design. We will have to focus on the 3rd action with NOC team to implement host based routing for the vSAN in order to avoid this issue in future. Agreed to close and talk to NOC.

Title: Multiple servers which are running as primary in Swindon moved to Stockley
Action: The VSAN VLAN sits in Stockley Park and this is the  only route.  If the Witness server loses visibility it will instigate a failover.  We therefore need to create a resilient route.
Action updates:
05/09: Discussed & agreed on the following,
Option 1  No design change.. instead.
- Setup a process to periodically check the status of the N7K Supervisors flash drive and where required run the flash recovery tool. This will prevent a recurrence of the need to reload the N7K to recover the flash drives.
- In the event of future maintenance windows required on the Nexus 7Ks, Dharma will disable VMware HA. This will prevent the automatic failover triggered by the witness.
- Note 1.. the Witness/VSAN environment will become redundant as part of the SP exit. The new Gen11 platform will use iSCSI protocol and not VSAN.
- Note 2.. This type of failure has only occurred twice in the last 9 years.
08/08: Redesigning for the witness server ongoing

Title: Network connectivity issue at stores on 29th June
Action: Identify the reason behind the power outage/recovery works impacting the secondary link in SP
Action updates: 09/07: We have now confirmed that the primary and secondary DIA link in SP is served by different datacentres at Vodafone. Our secondary DIA link is served through the Iver data centre where there was an unplanned power outage which caused the issue.

Title: Network connectivity issue at stores on 29th June
Action: Follow up with Vodafone to identify the root cause behind the issue
Action updates:
09/07: We have now confirmed that there was an unplanned power outage at Vodafone datacentre in Iver at 07:55 am on 29th June. Although, the traffic transmission kit was running with the help of backup battery, however, at 12:50, the backup battery ran out of charge resulting in the traffic to failover to Swindon DIA link.  This caused the first blip at 12:51. Power was restored by VF at 13:20 and our traffic therefore failed back to secondary DIA in SP resulting in the 2nd network blip



04/07: VF have advised of an unplanned power outage at Iver datacentre at 07:55 am on 29th June. We were further informed of some recovery works carried out by VF to fix the power outage between 12:00 and 13:00 which would have caused the issue. We have requested VF to ensure a detailed investigation with their technical engineers and provide a concrete update on root cause on 9th July. A follow up call has been scheduled.

07/11 - In CATE server, the system will restart daily from 12:00 am BST to 12:30 am BST and again from 5:00 am BST to 5:30 am BST. If the first restart fails, a batch file will run to attempt a second restart. If the second restart fails, it will be triggered using a keyword in the log file. If this attempt also fails, an acknowledgment email will be sent, and the restart will need to be performed manually. This setup dry run will be done tomorrow and Demo by tuesday/wednesday to deploy to prod

Title: Blank Home Page served to customers on desktop and mobile web
Action: Microsoft to provide information about the request that was cached- A ticket has been raised with Microsoft in order to provide information about the request that was cached. (There is a concern that this could be time critical
Action updates:
23/08:  Microsoft applied a fix to our subscription on the 5th Aug -- this has resolved the issue, not re-occured for a month. Microsoft provided RCA, Azure had race condition when unpacking the app zip. Fix was Azure-backend rollback of our subscription. No further action required.
12/08:  Microsoft were due to share RCA (root cause analysis) today, however we have received it yet . The RCA is being chased with Microsoft. Also, Monitor for reoccurrence of issue since Microsoft applied patch. 
05/08: Microsoft agreed Azure behaviour is unexpected by applying a patch to our subscription (in their backend).
22/07: Microsoft is perusing an alternative hypothesis: "Origin serving old versions, this was detected 24hrs after this incident occurred"
Serving the old origin version DID happen, but doesn't align time-wise with the most recent examples of 2 byte responses (eg 12th July).
Microsoft have found evidence that the old version of our code does exist on our base instances (inwwwroot). This should never get served because we use WEBSITE_RUN_FROM_PACKAGE Azure setting where our latest oynx deployment .zip package is mounted from /home/data/sitePackages to wwwroot  (docs of how it should work).
Our incident investigation found examples where that mounting-over-wwwroot failed..Microsoft are working on RCA why it failed.
09/07;A ticket has been raised with Microsoft in order to provide information about the request that was cached. (There is a concern that this could be time critical

Title: Secondary (active) network firewall in Stockley Park was unavailable
Action: Follow up with Fortinet to identify why the debug command had resulted in a spike in CPU utilisation in active firewall
Action updates:
18/07: We have confirmed with Fortinet that Whenever a new configuration change or any type of update package is received in the FortiGate, the OS will signal the IPS engine to always reload the engine configuration.
In some cases, this engine configuration reload is absolutely necessary (e.g. if rule is added/deleted). However, in the case of Malicious URL DB or a FortiSandbox Block list change, this reload is not required.  In circumstances where number of sessions is large, and/or when the firewall is processing many policies; and/or when configuration changes or AV/FSA update is too frequent  this can cause the IPS engine to become unnecessarily loaded, resulting in an observable CPU spike.  At times this CPU spike would result in traffic dropping, or IPS engine crashes.  
08/07: We are no longer running debugs.  Investigations continue with the more recent spike issue (July)
14/06: Investigations are underway with vendor Fortinet

Title: 35 BP stores unable to access Customer applications on honeywells
Action: Go back to Honeywell and ask if 5ghz is disabled in the config why was it deployed as enabled
Action updates:
27/06: We have used the same honeywell utility for a number of years to generate our configuration, various device level settings have keys which are either set to certain values, or they could be set to enabled or disabled.  The config file deployed as part of this change was set as : 5Ghz - Disabled,  however, when deployed for other config settings, this WIFI 5Ghz setting was applied (you would only expect this to happen when set to enabled).  
 Since this issue we have questioned the Honeywell team about why this occurred, they have now advised us that we should no longer be using this utility as it is old,  and advised us to use another utility to set our config, we were frustrated we were not informed by Honeywell that we should not to use the old utility until after the issue. 
With the new utility, a configuration setting can only applied as enabled, therefore, there is no longer the option for disabled, and this type of issue will no longer occur.

Title: 35 BP stores unable to access Customer applications on honeywells

Title: My HR application was inaccessible on 24/03
Action: Was there a proactive alert at Oracle which identified the issue? If not, feasibility of configuring one.
Action updates: Oracle proactively communicated an issue on non-prod and test environment through an alert  therefore there are no further concerns on proactive notification from Oracle.

Title: My HR application was inaccessible on 24/04
Action: Agree with Oracle on preventive measures to remediate a similar issue in future without causing an outage.
Action updates:
14/06: Oracle is implementing additional, more sensitive monitors, to catch and address this scenario quicker. New monitoring mechanism has been deployed in order to automatically detect and alarm on packet corruption.
07/06: There had been no further updates from Oracle. Kirsten Walker - head of product continues to chase. ETA: 17/06
We have agreed in the call to post these questions to Oracle and await their updates. There is no defined ETA yet.

Title: My HR application was inaccessible on 24/05
Action: Liaise with Oracle to identify the issue with their networking infrastructure causing the outage and the recovery steps performed to resolve the issue.
Action updates:
14/06: Oracle confirmed that a subset of the infrastructure supporting network services encountered a period of degraded performance, introducing latency which lead to the observed impact. Oracle identified that this specific infrastructure encountered an intermittent bit-flip scenario. A bit flip is a rare phenomenon where a single binary digit (bit) changes its value from 0 to 1 or vice versa. This will affect packet data and cause it to fail and drop.
07/06: There had been no further updates from Oracle. Kirsten Walker - head of product continues to chase. ETA: 17/06
We have agreed in the call to post these questions to Oracle and await their updates. There is no defined ETA yet.

Title: DataStage services were unavailable after the RHEL upgrade activity
Action: What caused third issue at 19:07 with OS level routing?
Action updates:
08/05: The new version picked up the layer2 config (internal routing) instead of public routing causing the issue. 
Technical details - In Red Hat Enterprise Linux8 the use of the global /etc/sysconfig/network file is deprecated, and specifying the gateway should now only be done in per-interface configuration files - Ethernet devices have a default route metric starting at 100, while logical interfaces like bond0 and bond1 start from 300 and onwards. If multiple bond interfaces are being used in the system, it is recommended to set explicit route metrics on each interface. This is because we cannot be certain which bond interface will load first during boot.
02/05: After the upgrade the network routing was changed.  There are two interfaces, one for publics traffic and the other for internal. After the upgrade the default routing was set to public, but after some time it switched to internal.  The internal route was removed manually and a debugging trace needs to be enabled in the next planned outage to see why it switched.

Title: Telephony issues in ROI and UK stores
Action: NLP team to provide a full written explanation of what was required by Twilio, what was done by the NLP team to fulfil this request and what caused the issue.  Also investigate why ROI stores were fully impacted and UK stores intermittently impacted.  This statement will also include granular detail of the discussions held prior to the change with Cyber and NOC teams.
Action updates:
Background:
Twilio are expanding the Interconnect media services (with new IPs) for calls in all regions.
Twilio also are expanding the RTP port range to 10000-60000 UDP (Twilio are doing that to be able to support more traffic per IP. The more ports you have you can support more calls. As Twilio mentioned in the change log They are making this change to improve the flexibility , reliability and scalability of voice products.)
This change improves the flexibility, reliability, and scalability of our Voice products.
Twilio are using the new new Media Service and expanded port ranges listed below for all Voice Interconnect traffic.
 
2. Technical Impact:
In order to enable these new Media Services:
The new IP addresses must be whitelisted on the Customer perimeter Palo Alto Firewalls.
Enable the changes on the Customer Twilio Console Voice Configuration General/ Enable New Voice Media IP Ranges settings - toggle/option button with the new IP addresses in listed.
3. Impact if not done:
Any new Interconnect connections created after November 16, 2023 will be configured to use the new IP and port ranges. Failure to do so may cause one-way audio and dropped calls.
 
4. What Caused the Issue?????
The Ip's must be whitelisted in all interconnect platforms.
 
These 4 Ip's did not allow the traffic as the new Ip Ranges from Twilio were not allowed.
185.168.95.200 legacy pool only
185.168.95.201 legacy pool only
185.168.95.232 legacy pool only
185.168.95.233 legacy pool only
 
This caused one way communication to happen. To resolve this, we need to add the new Ip Range to mitel and sabio firewall.
168.86.128.0/18
UDP port range: 10000-60000 (expanding from 10000-20000)
 
why ROI stores were fully impacted and UK stores intermittently impacted. Twilio suspect that at this point would be that have different network paths for each country. Prashant also mentioned that Irish calls go via Mitel which might have something to do with this.
Once the ip's were whitelisted, the twilio Team was notified about this and they asked us to toggle the new ip's. once we toggled the new ip's it caused one way traffic to happen and the calls were impacted.
 
5. Discussions held prior to the change with Cyber and NOC teams.
Nlp Team Action: Nlp Team had a call with Angelos from twilio to confirm what are the ip's required to whitelist.
After getting the Ip's, Nlp Team raised a tufin request 3125 to implement the change on feb 28th.
On march 18 it cleared cyber approval and went for implementation.
With Cyber Team, Nlp Team had discussed that it was additional ip's that were required to be whitelisted to improve flexiblity.

Title: Delay in D&F batch impacting ordering and allocations for C&H DC's
Action: What was causing the memory spike since the migration?
Action updates:
30/04 -There is no evidence to compare against the data point before the migration. The server is hosted in BY Azure like the earlier one before migration. This means that if there is any event when the servers are identified to be faulty then new virtual machines are assigned. In this case the issue was with the memory parameter of the database server. This required tuning or upliftment in the memory. We choose to uplift the memory since it was the quickest approach to solve the criticality.
17/04 -BY to check with the project/migration team if any logs exist before the migration and after the migration to identify a trend. Also to analyse if new migrated servers are having defect/issues

Title: Delay in D&F batch impacting ordering and allocations for C&H DC's
Action: Check on why the Swap memory was not working as expected on 11/04
Action updates:
30/04 -Memory swap is not a preferred approach. When it happens there needs to be appropriate action taken. Although new knew it, there were BY internal discussion to fine tune parameters in DB side to address the issue. Before we could conclude on the approach to be taken, the event happened on the day when the database server had low memory leading to performance challenges and slowness. The recommendation received from Red hat vendor is to tune the database and they have not pinpointed any particular action leading to the issue since memory swap is expected to cause such disruption. 

17/04 -A sev 1 case has been raised with Vendor Redhat for further investigations.

22/05: The Dotcom fesk clusters are reviewed to assess the handling of deployments and explore alternative deployment methods. It has been identified that a central image/configuration deployment model may not be suitable for the Dotcom fesk clusters due to the presence of customized configurations that need to be managed at the cluster level.
 
Additionally, the implementation of changes on both DR (Disaster Recovery) and Prod (Production) clusters simultaneously, especially in the aftermath of an incident at one location, has the potential to result in a complete outage of the application. This poses a significant risk to our resiliency and business continuity, potentially leading to a disruption in service.
 
These observations highlight the need to carefully evaluate deployment strategies and consider alternative approaches to ensure the stability and reliability of the Dotcom fesk AKS clusters. However, in the modernisation initiative of Cloud, its been considered to standardise the environment for platform clusters.

As we are still investigating root cause, this steps is to ensure we proactively identify issues before causing an impact.
06/05:  Zeeshan and team are discovering the possibilities how to setup alert for CPU part from application itself. Linux team has already setup the CPU alerts from their end and Platform teams receive the INC once the CPU threshold which is 85% breached. In this scenario, the CPU utilization had not breached and therefore, no incident was triggered. 
There is an existing dashboard within the platform to identify critical issues. However, in this case, there was a latency in the Impala service on three problematic servers  however, no alerts were triggered. Review the existing platform alerts for CPU and memory spike along with Cloudera and look at the feasibility of configuring additional alerts.

Title: Bigdata platform issues impacting the EIH data availability
Action: Why was the issue not identified within the platform proactively before being highlighted by the DataOps team?
Action updates:
20/05: A SOP has been created to document the required steps to troublshoot a query slowness issue to identify the cause of the problem.
 There are different Layers in this platform. Platform team (Amnomix) own the application layer, and didn't receive any alerts from application during the issue window.  There were no alerts on problematic host in Cloudera Dashboard. In the Cloudera application there is no mechanism to monitor the query   slowness like if any query taking more than an hour so alerts should be triggered. The query slowness needs to be reported by end user if any because query   slowness is related with many aspects like number of records being fetched, Partitions, Table size ,number of parallel queries running, Statistics updated or not   etc. Still, We will raise this with Vendor to check is there any way to monitor the query slowness even though there are no alerts on Cloudera Platform/ Impala   service.
Identify the rationale within the platform to conclude that it was healthy. Review the E2E system resources as an action to investigate platform issues.

Title: Sofa and Armchair PDPs showing a 503 error to customers
Action:
The traffic was very low on the Sofa and Armchair pages which meant that the warningthreshold for 503 alerts did not trigger. The threshold was set to 50 and the actual count of errors was 35. The threshold has already been changed to a lower number (30).

A new alert has been introduced to highlight when pods are not running. If 3 or more pods are in a pending (i.e. non-running ) state the alert will trigger.
Action updates: The alerts have been configured.

25/06: The changes can only be implemented once Donington has attained stability. There are multiple critical changes being deployed to the DC, however, this one being least critical will be deployed once the issue is resolved.

27/03: From the audit logs, it was identified that the impacted UPC was posted on the year 2023 and it looks like there has been a manual amendment of this UPC on 19/02//2024 which is not ideal. However, due to insufficient logs, the details around the manual amendment could not be identified. To identify these issues, a checkpoint is being tested in the integration environment which will capture the details if there are any manual amendments made on an existing UPC. Once this is tested successfully, the change will be deployed into production.
15/03: From the initial investigation, it seems like there was some manual posting performed which caused the issue. However, further analysis is being performed to avoid the scenario in future. 
Teams are investigating the log file. There is no change in SAP, it was sent with Foods assortment on 19/02, however, it was moved to C&H in ES, teams are investigating further.

Title: Customer Website not available and no orders placed UK, IE, International
Action: 5 preventative measures detailed in the Root Cause section
Action updates:
10/06 - IP Twins confirmed that they have completed the last action.
03/06 - Rehan has sent IP Twins the following regarding task 5 below - I am tracking the completion of this in our problem tracker and need to provide an ETA (I know you have now prioritised this)  what date do you suggest please?  Email alerts / record criticality We will implement email alerts sent to all Administrator and Technical users of the portfolio when a zone file update is performed and : - The zone file update covers more than 10 records at once, or - The zone file update covers records marked at critical on the zone file. We will implement a feature allowing to mark/unmark records as critical on the zone file of any domain name. 

1/ Alert message on zone file edition (do not refresh) IP Twins have already implemented a message indicating Caution : Do Not Refresh the Page while the zone file update is being sent to our master name server.Completed 4/3
2/ Diff comparison with production IP Twins will update the zone edition process by comparing the production zone file and the updated zone file : if the change is greater than 10 records, a pop-up message will be brought, that will (i) alert of the change, (ii) display the requested change, (iii) allow to confirm change and push to production or cancel and revert to the production zone file. Completed 18/3
3/ Alert message on current edition by another user IP Twins will block zone file edition to any user if a user is already working on the zone file of the same domain name. Priority will be given to the user that was first on the zone file, and the second user will be displayed a read-only zone file with no modification capabilities. A message will indicate that update is being performed by another user. Completed 18/3
4/ Rollback to last stable version The current UI allows to obtain zone file history and roll back in bulk by duplicating the zone file history. IP Twins will implement a rollback button to ease the process. The rollback will be performed up to the last stable version, i.e. a version with a DNS serial number which was in place for over 24 hours. Completed 18/3
5/ Email alerts / record criticality We will implement email alerts sent to all Administrator and Technical users of the portfolio when a zone file update is performed and : - The zone file update covers more than 10 records at once, or - The zone file update covers records marked at critical on the zone file. We will implement a feature allowing to mark/unmark records as critical on the zone file of any domain name. Estimated change implementation: in progress - 18/05 This has now been confirmed as prioritised by IP Twins.

Title: SAP POSDTA application unavailable
Action: What caused the overnight GMOR batches to miss their target completion times?
Action updates:
22/02: Job dependency has been added now to avoid the parallel run of the Ecom extractor. 
15/02: There was a parallel job execution in GMOR which was utilizing the same table, however, performing different operations. This caused data corruption in GMOR resulting in the batch delay. Therefore, a job dependency had been added to avoid the parallel run of the Ecom extractor.

Title: CD DC received Ecom nominated orders beyond the cut off time
Action: Add a process to validate the orders by ship by date and full fill the orders during any planned outages.
Action updates:
06/02: WMS consumes only a single date field from middleware which is populated to site users. Hence there is no specific validation that can be introduced advising users to refer an alternate date. Additionally, OMS confirmed over the PIR that going forward Delivery date will be amended instead of Shipment date which will ensure that the orders will not drop beyond their cut off time. As a best practice whenever, there is a long outage planned in site the below step can be included.
WMS team to add a step in the cutover to verify if there are open orders with change in proposition against OMS and advise site to pull forward the orders. This can be planned on the outage day.

Title: CD DC received Ecom nominated orders beyond the cut off time
Action: Can we change the reference of latest ship date to ship date in the WMS logic so the shipping calendar can be switched off only for Castle Donington
Action updates: 20/02:The feasibility of changing the reference of latest ship date to ship date in the WMS logic so the shipping calendar can be switched off only for Castle Donington is being explored under the back log JDATE-1032206/02: Though OMS feeds 2 types of date, from Middleware WMS receives only 1 date field that is populated to users. Any amendments required needs to be configured in EM/Middleware on which type of date WMS needs to consume. With Dispatcher upgrade scheduled to Go Live on April24 this change is not appropriate now. Post Dispatcher upgrade and MULE coming into the architecture, a decision can be taken after discussing with OMS, MULE and WMS teams.

Title: Missing EOD stock files for Foods Bradford impacting allocation
Action:
There is a dependency between the WMS file generation and the DS output job. There are 2 conditions configured in the DS job  1. ISM file process completion.

2. Pick face process completion. These conditions were set to OR to start the job in Datastage, therefore, the DS job completed successfully on 24/12. Configure proactive alerts in Datasatge to identify the issue before processing into the downstream systems.
Action updates:
24/04: The change was successful
22/04: Teams have have raised CRQ000000199626 for this change and planning to deploy on Wed(24/04) since there is a DS outage tomorrow.
05/04: There were some access issue in the DS non prod environment as it has been recently migrated to Cloud, this has been fixed now. ETA to deploy in prod - 17/04.
14/03: Due to ongoing DS outages, it is taking longer, Sreeraj has confirmed that he will provide an update by 21/03.
12/02: The issue with the WMS job which failed on the day, however, reflected "completed" in control M caused the confusion in DS. This has been sorted now. Additionally, a file watcher job is being configured in DS to ensure successful receipt of the files before processing to the downstream systems
It has been agreed to amend the DS job condition to AND to ensure both the files are received before the job starts executing.
Also, an additional file watcher job will be configured to verify the availability of the files.

Title: WCS Database Unavailable
Action: Review and understand the circumstances where failover should happen, and which conditions were not met in this case.  Validate that failover works where the scenarios are valid.  Review the overall resilience of the VM and the DB.
Action updates:
Update 23/01 -  Updated in the backlog ticket : MCIP-3686 to track this further.
Update 02/01: The observer will initiate failover to the target standby if and only if ALL of the following conditions are true.
	Observer is running  TRUE
	observer and the standby both lose contact with the primary - TRUE
	observer is still in contact with the standby - TRUE
	failover threshold timeout has elapsed - TRUE
	durability constraints are met  FALSE

During the issue time, all the above conditions were true except one as the logs says standby DB may not be synchronized with primary. As per Oracle support we will have to increase the value of TransportDisconnectedThreshold. Currently it is 30 seconds which is default value. Further investigation is in progress.

Update 15/01:  This action will start after action 67 - Jishin to raise a backlog

Title: WCS Database Unavailable
Action: What were all the ways the incident was detected?  Can we see if we can get an alert for the ASMB process and other critical processes not running?
Action updates:
Update 11/04 Prashant has raised a CR to capture the command history (with timestamp) for all Oracle databases in .com in Production not just WCS.  This has been deployed into production.
Update 23/01: Discussed with Prasanth Rowlo and he confirmed they are raising a production change to start capturing the command history along with timestamp this week.
Update 02/01: We have 10 critical background processes in Oracle and ASM instances. Process death of any of these processes will cause DB/ASM instance crash immediately. This process death will be captured in the alert log too indicating that which process was terminated. In our case also, we could clearly see that ASMB process was died; but we were not aware of  how did ASMB died?. So, if we enable alerting for these 10 processes; we will get 11 critical alerts (10 process down and 1 DB target down) in case if we bring down the DB or in case of any DB instance crash. However, this wont help us to avoid the issue or help much unless we check the alert log which we do it anyway. But any alerting or detailed auditing that helps to notify the team in the events of manually process termination/file deletion will help to identify the root cause easily.  Jishin to speak with CTL Ops Prashant to see if any alerting can be implented that notify if any processes are being terminated.

Action updates:

However, on Sunday during the weekly job all the UPCs were ambient UPCs causing compatibility issues. Also, it is observed that quantum is not compatible with higher java versions and as it is a legacy application, we are not able to drill down on its compatibility issue. 

As a preventive measure, new test case with significant load volume will be added as part of the standard testing procedure. For the permanent fix, Relex will be replacing quantum in next 9months  1 year.

Title: Quantum Job failure and WMS slowness impacting Bradford NDC allocations
Action: Root cause
Action updates:
There are two scenarios in this issue: 

1.	On 27/09, the Foods Critical job FOP309 failed due to a problematic UPC:
Foods Supply chain colleagues had raised a manual purchase order in Quantum with an incorrect (significantly high) order quantity. Due to this the application node went offline whilst processing the UPC resulting in job failure. As there is no restriction within SAP, while raising POs these scenarios cannot be prevented. However, there is a standard procedure agreed within the teams to handle the scenario by re-processing/skipping the problematic UPC

2.	Once the batch was recovered, Bradford DC reported slowness: Owning to the above Job failure, the bradford orders had started interfacing into WMS with a delay at 04:00. In parallel, there was a resource constraint (high CPU utilization) within one of the DB servers in the WMS system. The CPU spike was due to ad-hoc custom reports (10 hours data) generation by a DC colleague via a legacy print server.

Title: Quantum Job failure and WMS slowness impacting Bradford NDC allocations
Action: What preventive measures can be taken to avoid the delay in Batch?
Action updates:
Foods: Whenever a problematic UPC is identified, the UPC will be skipped as per the standard procedure.

WMS: DC Colleagues has been communicated not to run the reports on that time. Also, the legacy print server is planned to be migrated to the latest version. (to be planned in Jan24)

Title: HHT issue in Stoke DC
Action: What caused the increase in queue depth within the HHTs resulting in the issue?
Action updates: The cause of the queue depth is attributed to high volume of transactions due to the recent addition of Ecomm orders in Stoke DC. The transactions have been exceeding the queue depth limit of 16kb causing message pile-ups.

Title: HHT issue in Stoke DC
Action: What preventive measures can be taken to make the HHT daemon handle high volume/queue depth?
Action updates:
The Queue size has been increased to 1Mb during the Ecomm orders addition to Stoke DC and to reflect the uplift, the queue has been rebuilt. 

Also, Vendor BY has provided a new feature within the HHT Daemon to flush out the message pile-ups as and when the queue depth reaches 1Mb. This will avoid any manual intervention to fix the issue in future.

Title: Label printing issues at Welham Green DC
Action: Feasibility of identifying any alerting mechanism during a daemon restart in case of any missing files.
Action updates:
28/11: In general, any daemon will either fail to start or report it in the log, in case of missing of any mandatory files. But the problem on that specific issue was that the defaultlabel.xml is not a mandatory file for jrtskdae to start or even to work as usual in most of the cases. It is only needed for label printing except for those labels where a custom XML file contained absolutely everything. Hence we have seen that all the standard and custom reports were getting printed fine on that day. This kind of reporting of missing file by the daemons, is true not only for jrtskdae, but for other daemons as well. As this field is not mandatory file for daemon, no alerts cannot be configured by BY. 
10/11:BY case: 04946360 
The above case is raised with BY to advice if anything product team can do for alerting. We are yet to get any response
Kunal will work with Blue Yonder to address this.

Title: WMS application unavailable at Ollerton DC
Action: Liaise with RedHat to determine the cause of the file system corruption
Action updates: Redhat confirmed that the initial trigger point is token lost on the cluster due to network communication lost between 2 nodes. The failover cant happen without the reset of the system, leading to splitbrains. The xfs filesystem can not run into more than 1 node as this is active/passive filesystem, and this led to the filesystem corruption. In short, duplicate IP conflict overhead to File system corruption in above scenario.

Action updates: It has been confirmed from the logs that no network blips were observed at the site during the time of the issue

Title: Latency observed in HHTs at Swindon DC
Action: What caused the increase in the volume of data writing to the database resulting in the issue?
Action updates:
09/11: As part of combined deliveries project, a new piece of code was implemented 2 months back. The code was running with package logging on and it was writing large number of records in database whenever the receipt message from GIST DC was processed in Swindon DC. This usually comes between 11AM to 12PM on daily basis and during this period we see high number of records being written in database. On 26th there was slight increase in the volume and clubbed with other transaction being processed at same time, the DB reached its threshold on committing the DB transaction and started to slow down in processing these transactions, causing slowness in DC operations. 
Permanent fix: The package logging has been turned off now.
The below exercise is being performed to identify the spike in the data volume.  
1. Review the long running sessions, radius server.  
2. Review the DHL extract job to identify if it has contributed to the issue.

Title: Issue in POS sales flow in SAP POSDTA
Action: Reason behind the change failure
Action updates: As a part of the SAP monthly release on 22/09, a change was introduced to address an existing issue of message failures due to duplicate records insertion (combination of promotion lines with multiple discount types) in the POSDTA tables. On 23/09, there were additional and complex scenarios on the combination of promotion and discount types which resulted in POS sales messages not processing as expected. The root cause attributed to insufficient testing scenarios before the change implementation.

Title: Issue in POS sales flow in SAP POSDTA
Action: Proactive communication to the downstream systems
Action updates:
The issues started at 22:00 on 22/09, the downstream product teams were notified only at 05:30 on 23/09.

With the message pile up threshold determined; proactive communication will be sent to the consumers. 

Note: There was no impact on business due to delay in comms

Action updates:
This is a long term action, in parallel, the migration to cloud is also planned

Elizabeth to recommend platform options like Pure Storage etc.

In parallel, the plan to move CSSM to CLOUD is also lined up. ETA: by Sept 2024

Title: Performance issues in CSSM application
Action: What caused the hardware failure? Why the CSSM data rebuild took time as part of the recovery process?
Action updates:
A faulty hardware was detected in the ESXI host which serves the CSSM application virtual machines on 21/09 and 15:30 due to a memory module and array controller failure in the infrastructure. The faulty hardware was replaced on 23/09 and has remained stable.  
As part of the automatic recovery process, the CSSM data was rebuilt into the alternate host. It is believed that due to an increased usage of the CSSM application due to the time of the day, the data rebuild took longer resulting in the overrunning of multiple jobs and performance issues in CSSM.

Title: Performance issues in CSSM application
Action: Ascertain the stability of the problematic host after the hardware replacement. What is the plan to introduce the VMs to this host?
Action updates:
10/10: The host has remained stable with no issues observed with the introduction of the non-critical VMs.
The faulty hardware was replaced on 23/09 and the host has been stable for the past 4 days. 
VMware team are planning to introduce the non-critical VMs to this host and test the stability.

Title: Performance issues in CSSM application
Action: What caused the system resource contention on the CSSM application servers?
Action updates:
10/10: It is believed that during the data replication in the CSSM database servers on the alternate host, whist the web servers continuously tried to connect to the database servers for processing the messages, it resulted in the spike in memory consumption causing the delay in the message flow. However, there is no significant evidence to prove this. As a precaution, the CSSM web server memory is being uplifted on 08/10 from 6gb to 8gb


Initial analysis indicates an increase in the number of MQ explorer user sessions causing memory contention. However, the teams will regroup and perform a detailed analysis of the existing logs to ascertain the cause.

Title: Performance issues in CSSM application
Action: Uplift the memory of the CSSM web server. Configure an alert with a memory threshold. Create a SOP detailing the steps to bring down the memory
Action updates:
16/10: The memory has been uplifted. The alerts are in place. Monitoring is underway to identify the threshold value to avoid false alerts. 
After the memory uplift on the CSSM server on 22/09, it was identified that the memory utilization is spiking between 75-85%, therefore, a decision has been taken to further uplift the memory from 6gb to 8gb. 

Application to review the thresholds of the existing alert in CSSM.

A SOP to be created detailing the relevant steps to bring down the memory utilization incase the issue recurs.

Title: Drop in orders on website
Action:
Visibility of push timings and batch sizes
Given that the push notification sizes are being ramped up, there needs to 
be visibility of when the pushes are occurring and what size they are to 
wider teams. (E.g to Tech and Operational teams) This will help ensure that 
push notifications are not being carried out at a time when there is reduced 
capacity such as running on one hall
This ties into the performance testing (point 1). 
Discussed and agreed that the right people are in the relevant Teams 
channel. Given that it was a unique combination of events which triggered 
the excessive requests resulting from the push notification, there is no need 
to take special care regarding when the push notifications occur.

Title: Drop in orders on website
Action:
Improve error handling in Android App 
500 errors were encountered and instead of stopping network calls, the app 
kept on re-trying the request resulting in a large volume of spurious requests 
being sent to WCS . Improved error handling is required to prevent the 
continuous re-tries
Two errors are being fixed 1) Handling of re-retrying requests 2) Fix for 500s
Action updates: 10/10: The re-trying of requests on Android has been partially addressed, but the full solution will take a lot longer and isn't part of this resolution and it will be tracked under the JIRA back log

Title: Drop in orders on website
Action:
WCS Fix for requests being sent to Key Store
As a result of investigation into the code, it was identified that requests to 
the WCS key store to obtain the certificate to validate the token are 
occurring for each request. It is believed that this could be causing a block 
but this needs to be proved and if correct, a fix is required to obtain the 
certificate once (rather than for each request).
Action updates:
31/10: The fix has been deployed successfully 
10/10: The testing is still in progress and is planned to deploy  into production by 16/01
A fix has been coded and is currently in SIT2 waiting for performance testing 
w/c 25th September

Title: Drop in orders on website

Rate Limit Cap

what WCS can handle
Action updates:
31/10: The rate limit can be increased upto 20K, hence there is no fall back required 
Simon advised that loading testing is being carried out based upon the
parameters in place during the incident. The WCS fix will go in (point 3) and
then further load testing will take place. Based upon this testing, the rate

can then be matched to push notification batch size (point 4)

compromise business proposition, is there a fallback? This is part of a wider 
discussion

Title: Delay in Relex overnight batch
Action:
Root cause of the issue 

What caused the performance/slowness issue at Relex?
Why were empty store order proposal files generated on 10/09 after the Relex nightly run.
Action updates:
The distributed storage platform (Storage Grid) at Relex consists of 38 database nodes. One of the service responsible for replicating the data across the nodes according was stuck on one of the 38 nodes on 30/08. The stuck service exhausted available nodes by 6:00am BST 9/9, which resulted in the performance/latency in RELEX system
16/09: The performance/slowness issue in the Relex overnight batch was caused due to a faulty database node within the Storage Grid at Relex  managed by NetApp (3rd party supplier to Relex) due to a possible bug in the NetApp environment. This also resulted in the generation of empty store order proposal files on 10/09. However, Relex continue to investigate the detailed root cause analysis with NetApp and a follow  up call will be scheduled based on the feedback received from Relex.

Action: Whenever a change is deployed relating to intelligent routes a full end to end analysis of the routes will be carried out and added to the implementation plan.  Change management and NOC management to cascade this process to their teams.
